Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat noncompliances, identify why the previous CAP was
unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
Youth A has been inappropriately touched by Youth B in a cottage at the facility.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received on 01/07/22 and investigated jointly with DHHS
Specialist and DHHS Specialist 2 (who took over for the initial DHHS Specialist).
The original allegations are as follows,
Youth A (16) and an unknown male peer (age unknown) stay in a cottage
together at the Methodist Children's Home. A male resident, that shares a
cottage with Youth A, has been touching Youth A inappropriately when they are
in their cottage. No details are known regarding where the male peer has been
touching Youth A inappropriately or for how long this has been going on. It is
unknown if there are cameras in the cottage they reside in that would catch the
male peer's actions towards Youth A. The staff at Methodist Children's Home is
not aware of what the male peer is doing to Youth A. However, this is concerning
as Youth A's behaviors have been calm until recently as Youth A intentionally
scratched himself with an unknown object the other day. The staff at Methodist
Children's Home, his therapist, and Foster Care Worker are aware Youth A
intentionally scratched himself and are addressing this issue with him.
I interviewed the complainant on 01/10/22 via phone. The complainant clarified that
additional information was reported by Youth A during a home visit and the
information was passed on to the complainant. Reportedly Youth B was identified as
the youth who was touching Youth A and the two youth know one another from a
prior placement.
I interviewed Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) via phone on 01/10/22. The FCW
reported knowledge of the complaint and that Youth B was identified as the peer
who was allegedly touching Youth A. The FCW said that Youth A might have
confusion about what is appropriate given his cognitive level of about a seven- or
eight-year-old, or a second grader. The FCW said that Youth A’s trauma history
might skew his perception of what is appropriate or current, as well. The Methodist
therapist is currently working with Youth A about sexual and gender issues. She
didn’t have anything else to add. During a follow-up phone interview with the FCW,
on 01/20/22, the FCW said that she met with Youth A the day prior, and he reported
5

that Youth B slaps him in the arm and head. Reportedly, Youth A has told the staff
about this, but Youth B has continued to slap Youth A. Youth A reported nothing else
is happening.
Phone and email contacts with the DHHS Specialist were made until the case
assignment was transferred to DHHS Specialist 2. The first Specialist reported that
she had attempted to schedule a forensic interview for Youth A, but the appointment
was postponed multiple times for various reasons. Both Specialists reported that a
law enforcement notification was sent but was not going to be investigated unless
Youth A disclosed a weapon was involved during his forensic interview.
I interviewed Youth A with DHHS Specialist 2, on 01/24/22, at the facility related to
the medication and medical allegations outlined later in this report, but we did not
interview him related to this allegation as we were waiting for the forensic interview.
Youth A appeared clean and did not have any noticeable marks or injuries. He
confirmed that he changed cottages recently and noted things are going well.
I interviewed Youth B at the facility on 02/16/22, jointly with DHHS Specialist 2.
Youth B reported that he feels safe at the facility and gets along with other youth and
the staff. Youth B reported that he gets enough to eat, and meals often include
vegetables. Youth B said that he “loves messing with people” as he proceeded to
put things on my papers, played with DHHS Specialist 2’s phones, and messed with
the hand sanitizer on the table. Youth B said that he gets along with Youth A and
noted that they were in a previous placement together as well. Youth B denied
hitting other kids and said he would only hit someone if he felt threatened. He denied
having fights with or hitting Youth A.
I interviewed Staff 3 and Staff 4 at the facility on 02/16/22, jointly with DHHS
Specialist 2. Both staff reported having worked in the cottage with Youth A and
Youth B prior to them being separated. Both staff said that Youth B actively
horseplays and touches/hits Youth A (and other kids) but neither reported this to be
aggressive or hurtful. The staff try to redirect Youth B, which is sometimes
successful, but Youth B periodically continues to horseplay. Neither staff reported
Youth B to hit Youth A aggressively. Neither staff reported witnessing any sexualized
touching between the two youth.
I interviewed Youth C and Youth D at the facility on 02/16/22, jointly with DHHS
Specialist 2. Both youth reported feeling safe at the program and both were familiar
with Youths A and B. Youth C reported no horseplay, no youth hitting one another
and no youth intentionally aggravating one another. The only youth who was
identified as bothering him, was a different peer that Youth C reported to be “gay.”
Youth D reported that some youth horseplay, including one peer and Youth B. Youth
D said that Youth B will poke or tap other kids, touches kids without permission (not
sexually), always asks people for a fist bump, and will sometimes intentionally stand
in others’ way. Youth D said it doesn’t bother him now but was aggravating initially.
Youth D said that no one is hurting anyone, and Youth B doesn’t seem to be doing
6

these things to hurt others. Youth D added that staff do intervene and tell Youth B to
stop and sometimes he stops but will usually do something again the next day.
I received the notes from Youth A’s forensic interview, on 02/28/22, from DHHS
Specialist 2. Per the health and safety regulations of the organization conducting the
interview, I was not allowed to attend the interview that occurred on 02/10/22. DHHS
Specialist 2’s summary of the interview noted no report by Youth A of being hit,
touched, or otherwise harmed at the facility. Youth A was able to differentiate
between appropriate/good touching and inappropriate/bad touching. He reported
feeling safe at the facility and noted that staff are there to keep the children safe.
Youth A said that he only feels unsafe if kids are fighting and noted that staff
intervene to stop this from occurring. Youth A also reported in the interview that he
feels safe with the other residents and has never felt unsafe.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation includes:
 Safety plans for both Youth A and Youth B were developed and provided by
the facility. Youth A moved to another cottage and the two were to be kept
separated. Staff were to increase line of sight supervision pending the
investigation. Signed by the Clinical Director and dated 01/20/22.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: The facility is compliant with the rule as there is no evidence that
staff are not sufficiently supervising youth and allowing Youth A
to be inappropriately touched or hit. This was not supported by
the interviews, including Youth A’s forensic interview.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
7

ALLEGATION:
Youth A’s medical and medication needs are not being met at the facility. Youth B
has missed one medication and Youth X is overdue for a dental exam.
INVESTIGATION:
Additional allegations were received on 01/20/22 and added to this investigation.
These allegations were investigated jointly with DHHS Specialist 2. The allegations
were as follows,
Youth A has diabetes. Since 12/28/2021, Youth A's blood sugar has been high.
On 12/28/2021, Youth A's blood sugar was 374. Youth A's blood sugar has been
above 150 since 12/28/2021. Youth A's endocrinologist provided a diabetic
hotline that the staff should utilize if Youth A's blood sugar goes above 150. The
staff has not been utilizing the hotline. It is unknown if Youth A has been
impacted negatively. Youth A’s cardiologist also provided a specific diet for the
staff to follow. The staff have not been following the recommendations of the
cardiologist. The facility did receive the dietary recommendation; however, they
did not follow the recommendation because it did not come from a nutritionist.
Not following the recommended diet could have a significant impact on Youth A’s
health and may be a contributing factor in Youth A’s blood sugar not being under
control. In addition, Youth A has not been receiving his medication as prescribed.
Youth A has been allowed to leave the facility without his insulin and Youth A has
also missed medical appointments. There is an overall concern for Youth A’s
health as diabetes is a serious medical condition that has to be appropriately
managed to avoid detrimental outcomes. There are several other youth at
Methodist Children's Home that are not receiving the appropriate amount of
medical care as well.
On 01/20/22, Consultant 2 forwarded information, via email, related to the
allegations of the “other youth” noted in the complaint. It was alleged that Youth B
was sent on a home pass without one of his medications and Youth X had a late
dental exam.
I interviewed Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) via phone on 01/10/22. The FCW
reported that Youth A was due for a dental exam in December, but it was still not
done. The FCW said that Youth A’s facility case manager has advised her that he
has an appointment set for tomorrow. The FCW said that Youth A was supposed to
have a cardiologist appointment set up months ago, but due to delays with the
facility, the FCW is setting up and taking Youth A to these appointments herself. The
FCW said that medical follow-up appears to have “fallen apart” since the former
nurse left the facility. During a follow-up phone interview with the FCW, on 01/20/22,
the FCW said that she found out the day prior, from the Therapist, that Youth A’s
blood sugar levels have been high. The FCW said that the Therapist reported that
she would remind the staff what they are supposed to do. The FCW said that the
8

dental exam was finally done but Youth A didn’t get a cleaning, just an exam, per the
record. Regarding Youth A’s cardiology appointment, the FCW said that she makes
those appointments and made an appointment for February. The FCW will also take
Youth A to this appointment. Additionally, the FCW said that she made an
appointment for Youth A to go to the diabetes clinic March 10, 2022, and noted she
will take him to that appointment also.
I exchanged emails with Youth B’s Foster Care Worker, on 01/20/22, related to the
allegation of him missing medication during a home pass. This Foster Care Worker
clarified the allegation and reported, “Youth B visited the foster home of the former
foster parents this past weekend and yesterday they mentioned he did not have all
medication for weekend. I reached out this morning for clarification. The foster dad,
responded, ‘1 morning med. Youth B wasn’t sure what it was, and we do not receive
a medication list, so I am not sure either. It was not his lithium’.”
I interviewed the Therapist at the facility on 01/24/22, jointly with DHHS Specialist 2.
The Therapist has worked with Youth A since June of 2021.The Therapist denied
that the facility or cottage provides youth with many sugary items. She reported that
Youth A told the Therapist he was “feeling off” and thinking that his medication might
need adjusting. When the Therapist reviewed Youth A’s blood sugar levels, she
noticed they were high, particularly with the colder weather arriving and Youth A
being inside more and less active. The Therapist said that the school was not aware
Youth A was diabetic but noted that they should have been. Per the Therapist, Youth
A has been getting sugary items from school and from the nearby gas station, as
well as from his grandparents during home visits. The Therapist said that she has
relayed this information to the doctor. Youth A takes Metformin for his diabetes and
was just recently prescribed insulin as well. The Therapist said that she
communicates regularly with Youth A and his Foster Care Worker about his diet and
how to manage his diabetes. The Therapist said that she reviews the logs for Youth
A’s blood sugar and contacts the Foster Care Worker if there’s an issue. Due to
Youth A’s consistently high blood sugar levels they implemented a medical safety
plan as well. The Therapist said that she was not aware the FCW wanted them to
call a hotline until the FCW sent the endocrinology report last week. The Therapist
said that the hotline number, the FCW’s number, and the medical safety plan are all
in Youth A’s cottage now. Regarding home visits, the Therapist said that the staff
pack the medications and send them. When asked who facilitates Youth A’s
endocrinology appointments and cardiology appointments, the Therapist stated it
was the FCW. The Therapist said that the facility Nurse coordinates dental
appointments. The Therapist recalled Youth A missed one dental exam, about two
weeks ago, when he had to get picked up as his attorney showed up unannounced
at the facility to meet with him.
I interviewed Youth A with DHHS Specialist 2, on 01/24/22, at the facility. Youth A
entered the room with a shoebox that he was carrying with him. Youth A showed us
that the box contained Reese’s peanut butter cups, M&Ms, and cookies. Youth A
reported that he received the Reese’s from friends at school, the M&Ms from
9

Director 3, and the cookies were from his grandmother and brought back from his
visit with his grandparents. Youth A continued to eat candy throughout the interview,
even while acknowledging that he is not supposed to, as he is diabetic. Youth A
reported he was on a home pass over the weekend with his grandparents and ate a
burger, onion rings, and spaghetti. Youth A said that he does test his blood sugar
and said it will be high if he’s eating candy. Youth A tests his blood himself and staff
records the reading. Youth A was asked about his medication and reported that he
receives all his medications. He said that one time he went home on a visit and
thinks he missed one medication. Youth A couldn’t recall what medication or when
this occurred, noting it was likely in the fall or winter. If his blood sugar levels are
high, he is instructed to drink more water and retest. Youth A said that he also tests
his blood sugar during his home visits, either with his own meter or with his
grandmother’s. Youth A said that he is not on a special diet yet. Youth A reported
that he usually eats fried food and stated that there is not much healthy food at the
facility, like salads or vegetables. When asked about his exercise, Youth A reported
that there are options available to him at the facility (such as sports and gym time)
and that staff encourage him to participate in physical activity, but Youth A refuses
as he doesn’t like exercising. Youth A acknowledged that his doctors want him to
exercise but he doesn’t want to and stated that he is not going to.
I interviewed Director 3 at the facility on 01/24/22, jointly with DHHS Specialist 2. I
asked Director 3 if she provided Youth A with some candy M&Ms. Director 3 said
that she was talking to Youth A, who had come in her office while she was eating
candy, and she offered him some candy as well. Director 3 apologized for the error
and said that she just wasn’t thinking about his diabetes, but she is usually mindful.
I interviewed Staff 1 and Staff 2 at the facility on 01/24/22, jointly with DHHS
Specialist 2. Both staff reported regular testing of Youth A’s blood sugar and logging
of the results. It was further reported that staff will either advise the supervisor or log
the numbers in the log if very high. Both staff stated the Nurse checks the
documentation of the blood sugar checks. Both staff reported that Youth A often
brings back candy and “junk” from home passes and from school and hides it. Both
staff reported that they, and other staff, encourage Youth A to make better eating
choices, but Youth A continues to eat things he is not supposed to have. Both staff
reported that Youth A has access to exercise options. Staff 1 said that Youth A
refuses to participate in gym time or physical activity. Staff 2 said that Youth A plays
guitar and walks around. Both staff reported that Youth A gets the same dinner as
the other youth. Meals are sent over by the kitchen staff to the cottages. Staff 1 said
that there are not always vegetables at dinner, but she tries to find some at the
cottage to add to the meal if there are not vegetables included. Staff 2 said that there
are vegetables every day in the youth’s meals and some others at the cottages as
well.
I interviewed Staff 3 and Staff 4 at the facility on 02/16/22, jointly with DHHS
Specialist 2. Both staff have assisted Youth A in testing his blood sugar and
dispensing medications. Staff 3 said that his levels have been high. When that
10

occurs, staff are to tell the Nurse and give him water. Staff 4 said that Youth A
sometimes refuses medications. Staff 4 said when his blood sugar tests high the
staff lets the on-call supervisor know and the supervisor calls the Nurse, who may
then come to see the youth. Both staff reported that Youth A sneaks candy and
sweets into the cottage and sneaks extra snacks from the kitchen. The staff do
searches and do confiscate items if the youth are not supposed to have it.
I met with Director 1 on 02/16/22, jointly with DHHS Specialist 2. Director 1 reported
that Youth A’s FCW makes the appointments for Youth A for his cardiologist and
endocrinologist and also takes Youth A to those appointments. Director 1 said that
there was not a prescribed diet for Youth A, although recommendations/suggestions
were made.
In follow-up emails with Youth A’s FCW on 03/02/22, she reported that she provided
the facility a book that included blood glucose testing instructions for Youth A and a
list of contacts for the doctor office if Youth A tests over 200. The book and nutrition
information were reportedly provided to the Nurse on 1/26/2022. I asked the FCW
when the diet recommendations were provided to the facility and she replied that the
facility Nurse and Family Transition Coordinator now have the recommendations and
noted that she was going to take the diet paperwork to the facility on 03/02/22, along
with blood testing forms that must be completed in May and August. The FCW said
that it was the Family Transition Coordinator who advised her that the facility does
not follow dietary recommendations unless it is from a nutritionist. The FCW said
that Youth A was prescribed the Insulin on 01/21/2022 but noted that the facility did
not receive the medication until after 01/26/2022. The FCW added that additional
changes were made at the endocrinologist appointment at 01/26/22.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation includes:
 Youth A’s dental records were reviewed. It was observed that he was seen on
the following dates:
o 04/29/21-exam, x-rays, cleaning; needs fillings
o 05/18/21-fillings received
o 01/18/21-exam, x-rays
 Youth A’s medication administration records for January 2022:
o Several medications were observed as not having documentation of
administration for various days. It appears at least one dose of six
different medications was not documented as having been dispensed
to Youth A on at least one occasion during the month. There were no
staff initials in the box to record having administered the medication
and there was no reason code or exception noted for why the
medication was missed (i.e., refused, provided to family for home visit,
etc.)
 Youth A’s medication administration record for December 2021 was reviewed
specifically for glucose testing. It was observed that three days omitted
documentation of testing and did not record a reason for not testing. It
11

appears these day incidents were during home passes and staff did not
document all of them as such, however, others contained this documentation.
 Youth X’s dental records were reviewed. It was observed that he was seen on
the following dates and appears current on his dental needs:
o 06/09/21-exam, x-rays, cleaning and referred to orthodontist
o 06/25/21-orthodontist exam; no treatment needed
o 12/20/21-exam, x-rays, cleaning, fluoride; needs dental fill
o 01/11/22-dental fillings under local anesthesia
 Youth B’s medication administration records for the weekend of 1/14-1/16/22.
The records showed that Youth B was prescribed two morning medications,
Lithium and Vitamin D3. The documentation showed that the Lithium was
provided to the family for the duration of the home pass but did not outline the
Vitamin D3 for 1/15/22 and 1/16/22. It was additionally observed on the
January medication administration record for January 2022, that Youth A was
noted by staff to be out of medication on 01/07/22 and 01/08/22 for three
psychotropic medications. Vitamin D3 was also documented by the staff to be
out of refills on January 9, 11, 22, and 23.
 Youth A’s medical safety plan, developed with Youth A’s Foster Care Worker,
dated 01/19/22. The plan was signed by the facility Therapist on 01/14/22
with notes that it was reviewed and updated 01/19/22 and 01/21/22. It was
signed by the Nurse on 01/19/22. The plan outlines for Youth A’s blood sugar
to be tested twice a day, to follow dietary recommendations and food
restrictions, and for Youth A to exercise 30 minutes a day four to five days per
week. If results are over 200 the staff are to notify the FCW and call the
hotline if the FCW is not available. If over 300 the staff are to test Youth A’s
urine. Incident reports are to be written if he refuses a meal and the staff are
to notify the Therapist.

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
(e) Dispensing medication.
MDHHS FOM Policy 801-01 Health Requirements
Dental Examination Schedule: A dental re-examination shall
be obtained at least every six months, unless a greater
frequency is indicated.
ANALYSIS: (a) The dental records showed that Youth A was overdue for a
dental. Youth A had a dental exam on 04/29/21 and did not
receive another dental until 01/18/22. Youth are to receive
dental every six months and Youth A was almost three months
late when he received the January exam. Additionally, a review
of documentation in December specific to blood glucose testing
for Youth A found that there were three days with no
documentation of testing and no reason for not testing. Although
it appears these incidents were during Youth A’s home passes,
13

the facility must ensure proper documentation and reasons for
not testing (i.e., refused, on a home pass).
Regarding the allegations that Youth X was overdue for a dental
exam, the facility is compliant with the rule. The documentation
provided shows that Youth X has received appropriate dental
exams, cleanings, x-rays, follow up care for orthodontist
examination, and dental fillings.
(e) In regard to the allegations that Youth A was not receiving
his insulin, the facility is compliant. The documentation and
interviews show that the complaint was made prior to Youth A
being prescribed the insulin. This was verified by the facility
documentation and in the report from Youth A’s Foster Care
Worker. Administration of insulin began 01/28/22. The facility is
noncompliant with the medication dispensing rule, however, as
a review of Youth A’s medication administration record for
January 2022 found that the facility did not document dispensing
every prescribed dose of medication for Youth A. Six different
medications were observed to have missing documentation for
at least one dose during the month of January. The facility also
violated the rule as it was found that the allegation that Youth B
was sent home for a visit without one of his morning
medications was true. In this case, there was no documentation
of the facility providing the Vitamin D3 for 01/15/22 and
01/16/22. This is consistent with the report made by Youth B’s
Foster Care Worker that Youth B was missing one of his
morning medications during that weekend home pass. Finally,
Youth B’s record showed he was out of medication or refills for
various medications during the month. The facility is responsible
for ensuring youth have prescribed medications onsite and
available.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
